20110104140620.000|20110104140623.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Right.  You know one of the big 
20110104140623.000|20110104140625.000|TR0|costs of seniors, especially if they're on 
20110104140625.000|20110104140628.000|TR0|a lot of medications, is the cost of those 
20110104140628.000|20110104140630.000|TR0|drugs and one of the terms that gets 
20110104140630.000|20110104140633.000|TR0|bandied around a lot is the doughnut hole. 
20110104140633.000|20110104140635.000|TR0|Most of you know what it means by now.  
20110104140635.000|20110104140637.000|TR0|But basically, it means that you get 
20110104140637.000|20110104140640.000|TR0|through the first part of the doughnut, 
20110104140640.000|20110104140642.000|TR0|there you're getting some help from the 
20110104140642.000|20110104140645.000|TR0|government.  You're paying about 25 
20110104140645.000|20110104140647.000|TR0|percent of the cost of your prescription 
20110104140647.000|20110104140650.000|TR0|drugs.
20110104140650.000|20110104140652.000|TR0|
20110104140652.000|20110104140654.000|TR0|You get to the middle of the doughnut, 
20110104140654.000|20110104140657.000|TR0|you're not getting any help until you get 
20110104140657.000|20110104140659.000|TR0|to the other side of the doughnut.  And 
20110104140659.000|20110104140702.000|TR0|those are the thresholds.  So once you 
20110104140702.000|20110104140704.000|TR0|spent $2800, you don't get any help 
20110104140704.000|20110104140707.000|TR0|anymore until $4500, then you start to get 
20110104140707.000|20110104140709.000|TR0|help again.  It's that hole in the middle 
20110104140709.000|20110104140711.000|TR0|that people have been focused on for some 
20110104140711.000|20110104140714.000|TR0|time trying to shrink it, trying to make 
20110104140714.000|20110104140716.000|TR0|the impact of it less significant for 
20110104140716.000|20110104140719.000|TR0|seniors.
20110104140719.000|20110104140721.000|TR0|
20110104140721.000|20110104140724.000|TR0|So what they're saying now is that if 
20110104140724.000|20110104140726.000|TR0|you're spending a lot of money on drugs, 
20110104140726.000|20110104140728.000|TR0|once you get to the doughnut hole, the 
20110104140728.000|20110104140731.000|TR0|prescription drugs are going to cost 50 
20110104140731.000|20110104140733.000|TR0|percent of what they cost instead of 100 
20110104140733.000|20110104140736.000|TR0|percent. So you get help especially if 
20110104140736.000|20110104140738.000|TR0|you're some who's on a lot of medications.
20110104140738.000|20110104140741.000|TR0|
20110104140741.000|20110104140743.000|TR0|Ultimately they want to get rid of the 
20110104140743.000|20110104140745.000|TR0|doughnut hole altogether so have some sort 
20110104140745.000|20110104140748.000|TR0|of cost that you pay each time you get 
20110104140748.000|20110104140750.000|TR0|drugs, whether that's 25 percent or some 
20110104140750.000|20110104140753.000|TR0|fraction, but there's not these thresholds 
20110104140753.000|20110104140755.000|TR0|that have been set up that have prevented 
20110104140755.000|20110104140758.000|TR0|people from continuing to buy medications

20110104140832.000|20110104140834.000|TR0|In the meantime, there's something known 
20110104140834.000|20110104140836.000|TR0|as the preexisting condition insurance

20110104140844.000|20110104140846.000|TR0|that, are eligible for this plan.  How 
20110104140846.000|20110104140849.000|TR0|many people have signed up so far?  About 
20110104140849.000|20110104140851.000|TR0|8,000 out of 5 million.  So, you know,

20110104140858.000|20110104140901.000|TR0|
